citation.article-title: Phylogenetic Analysis of Five Strains of Gram-Negative, Obligately Anaerobic, Sulfur-Reducing Bacteria and Description of Desulfuromusa gen. nov., Including Desulfuromusa kysingii sp. nov., Desulfuromusa bakii sp. nov., and Desulfuromusa succinoxidans sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Desulfuromusa bakii sp. nov.
Desulfuromusa bakii (ba'ki.i. M. L. gen.n. bakii, of Bak, named in memory of Friedhelm Bak, who made important contributions to our knowledge of sulfur- and sulfate-reducing bacteria)

Cells are 0.5 to 0.6 μm wide and 2 to 4 μm long when they are grown with elemental sulfur as the electron acceptor, Nitrate, dimethyl sulfoxide and Fe(III)-citrate are not utilized as electron acceptors.
No growth occurs with aspartate or maleate without additional electron acceptors.
Citrate, acetate, pyruvate, lactate, propionate, oxalacetate, succinate, maleate, alanine, glutamate, aspartate, and yeast extract are used as electron donors.
Strains can be cultivated in defined medium without addition of complex nutrients like yeast extract or peptone.
No growth occurs in the presence of NaCl and MgCl2 concentralions of 114 and 3.3 mM, respectively.
The optimum pH for growth is between 6.7 and 7.4, and the minimum and maximum pH values for growth are 6.2 and 7.8, respectively.
The minimum temperature for growth is 8°C; the maximum temperature for growth is 32°C; and the optimum temperature is between 25 and 30°C.
The type strain of Desulfuromusa bakii is strain Gyprop (= DSM 7345); the G+C content of its DNA is 46 mol%.
Desulfuromusa bakii GypropT was isolated from an anoxic mud sample collected from Guayamas Basin (Gulf of California) at a depth of about 2,000 m.
The habitat of Desulfuromusa bakii Kyprop is the anoxic mud of the shallow Kysing Fjord south of Århus, Denmark.
